Citation_Information.description: GRaND level 1b Ceres ephemeris, pointing and geometry

Modification_Detail.description: PDS4 migration of GRD-L1B-150313-181026_190117-EPG.TAB from PDS3 dataset DAWN-A-GRAND-3-RDR-CERES-COUNTS-V1.0

Investigation_Area.name: DAWN MISSION TO VESTA AND CERES

Internal_Reference.comment: Dawn's gamma ray and neutron detector: Ephemeris, pointing & geometry at Vesta and Ceres
Shape model used in solid angle calculations: STereoLithography (STL) format (binary)

External_Reference.reference_text: Prettyman T.H., Feldman W.C., McSween H.Y., Jr., Dingler R.D., Enemark D.C., Patrick D.E., Storms S.A., Hendricks J.S., Morgenthaler J.P., Pitman K.M. & Reedy R.C. (2011) Dawn's gamma ray and neutron detector. Space Science Reviews, 163, 371-459.

Prettyman T.H., Mittlefehldt D.W., Yamashita N., Lawrence D.J., Beck A.W., Feldman W.C., McCoy T.J., McSween H.Y., Toplis M.J., Titus T.N., Tricarico P., Reedy R.C., Hendricks J.S., Forni O., Le Corre L., Li J.Y., Mizzon H., Reddy V., Raymond C.A. & Russell C.T. (2012) Elemental mapping by Dawn reveals exogenic H in Vesta's regolith. Science, 338, 242-6.

Prettyman T.H., Yamashita N., Toplis M.J., McSween H.Y., Schorghofer N., Marchi S., Feldman W.C., Castillo-Rogez J., Forni O., Lawrence D.J., Ammannito E., Ehlmann B.L., Sizemore H.G., Joy S.P., Polanskey C.A., Rayman M.D., Raymond C.A. & Russell C.T. (2017) Extensive water ice within Ceres' aqueously altered regolith: Evidence from nuclear spectroscopy. Science, 355, 55-59.

Table_Character.description: This time series data set contains ephemeris, pointing and geometry (EPG) data for the GRaND instrument during Ceres encounter. A detailed description of the methods and parameters are provided in the Ephemeris, Pointing and Geometry document included in the bundle.

Field_Character.name: SCLK
Field_Character.description: SCLK ticks at the end of the science accumulation interval (1s precision). SCLK serves as a 9-digit serial code that uniquely identifies each science data record. GRaND L1A and L1B science data files include SCLK as an identifier, such that values for the same record can be easily identified in different tables.

Field_Character.name: SCET_UTC
Field_Character.description: UTC S/C event time (SCET) at the midpoint of the science accumulation interval, determined by SPICE time conversion routines given TELREADOUT and the SCLK value marking the end of the interval.

Field_Character.name: ET_MID
Field_Character.description: Ephemeris time at the midpoint of the science accumulation interval (s), determined by SPICE time conversion routines given TELREADOUT and the SCLK value marking the end of the interval.

Field_Character.name: PHASE
Field_Character.description: Abbreviation for the mission phase. See dawnmission.cat for definitions of mission phases.

Field_Character.name: TELREADOUT
Field_Character.description: Length of the accumulation interval (s).

Field_Character.name: LIVE_TIME
Field_Character.description: Live time (s). Values are provided for science records for which the associated SOH packets can be identified. Otherwise, MISSING_CONSTANT is listed.

Field_Character.name: LON
Field_Character.description: Spacecraft longitude at the midpoint of the accumulation interval in Ceres' fixed frame.

Field_Character.name: LAT
Field_Character.description: Spacecraft latitude at the midpoint of the accumulation interval in Ceres' fixed frame.

Field_Character.name: DIST
Field_Character.description: Distance of the spacecraft to body center at the midpoint of the accumulation interval.

Field_Character.name: POS_X
Field_Character.description: Spacecraft position (X) at the midpoint of the accumulation interval in Ceres' fixed frame.

Field_Character.name: POS_Y
Field_Character.description: Spacecraft position (Y) at the midpoint of the accumulation interval in Ceres' fixed frame.

Field_Character.name: POS_Z
Field_Character.description: Spacecraft position (Z) at the midpoint of the accumulation interval in Ceres' fixed frame.

Field_Character.name: DIR_U
Field_Character.description: Body-center direction in S/C frame (x cosine) at the midpoint of the acccumulation interval.

Field_Character.name: DIR_V
Field_Character.description: Body-center direction in S/C frame (y cosine) at the midpoint of the acccumulation interval.

Field_Character.name: DIR_W
Field_Character.description: Body-center direction in S/C frame (z cosine) at the midpoint of the acccumulation interval.

Field_Character.name: SOLID_ANGLE
Field_Character.description:
Solid angle subtended by Ceres at the spacecraft.
The measurement geometry is determined by the solid angle subtended by Ceres at the spacecraft (with units of steradians). Counting rates, with background contributions removed, vary in proportion to the solid angle. Thus, the solid angle values can be used to remove measurement geometry effects to reveal compositional variations on the surface of Ceres.
SOLID_ANGLE was determined using the methods described by Prettyman et al. (2011, 2012, 2017) using a Digital Terrain Model provided by the Dawn navigation team (CERES_SURVEY_150716_GRAVITY_SPC). The interconnected quadrilateral (ICQ) format was converted to a triangle-vertex model, which was decimated, retaining 1% of the triangles. The decimated shape model used for the solid angle calculation is provided in STereoLithography (STL) format (binary) and as a Type 1 triangle-vertex file (ascii).

Field_Character.name: EQUIVALENT_ALTITUDE
Field_Character.description:
Equivalent altitude of the spacecraft if Ceres were a sphere of 469.7 km radius. Calculated from the solid angle.
The spacecraft EQUIVALENT_ALTITUDE (km) was also determined for each science accumulation interval from SOLID_ANGLE. The EQUIVALENT_ALTITUDE is the distance from a sphere of the same volume as Ceres (with a radius, R_EQ of 469.8km) that gives the same SOLID_ANGLE as determined from the shape model:
EQUIVALENT_ALTITUDE = R_EQ / sqrt{ 1 - [ 1 - SOLID_ANGLE/(2*PI) ]^2} - R_EQ

Field_Character.name: SUBSAT_DIST
Field_Character.description: Distance to the sub-satellite point in the body-center direction.

Field_Character.name: TRIPLES_RATE
Field_Character.description:
Counting rate for coincidences between three or more sensors, used as a proxy for the galactic cosmic ray flux. Values are provided for science records for which the associated SOH packets can be identified. Otherwise, MISSING_CONSTANT is listed.
TRIPLES_RATE is a proxy for the interaction rate of galactic cosmic rays (GCR) with the instrument and can be used to correct for temporal variations in gamma ray and neutron production within the regolith of Ceres. Large deviations from the local mean of the time series may be due to solar energetic particle events, cycling of the instrument state (e.g. power-on and HV ramp up), or other conditions, including corrupt data.

Field_Character.name: INSTR_CONFIG
Field_Character.description:
Instrument configuration - During Ceres encounter, different combinations of instrument settings (states) were used to acquire science data. An instrument configuration index (INSTR_CONFIG) is provided to indicate operational state. Allowed values include:
INSTR_CONFIG=0: The instrument was not fully configured for science data acquisition.
INSTR_CONFIG>0: The instrument was fully configured. INSTR_CONFIG indicates the combination of high voltage settings that were used.
High voltage setting (data number, DN) INSTR_CONFIG HV1 HV2 HV3 HV4 HV5 HV6 1 180 170 175 180 125 170 2 185 170 175 180 125 170 3 180 170 175 180 127 170 4 185 173 178 182 127 170 5 185 173 178 182 123 170 6 180 170 175 180 119 170 7 180 170 175 180 121 170 8 180 170 175 180 123 170 9 180 170 175 180 128 170 10 185 173 178 182 121 170 11 185 173 178 182 119 170 (Note: 1500 V per 255 DN)

Field_Character.name: T_BGO
Field_Character.description: BGO temperature reading averaged over the science accumulation interval. The BGO temperature data is useful for idenfiying times when GRaND's internal temperatures have stabilized following power on. The sensor is well isolated with a thermal time constant of about 24 hours.
